data.name: paragraph
data.body: Diamagnetism is a property of certain materials where they repel from stronger magnetic fields and move towards weaker ones. When exposed to an external magnetic field, these materials weaken their internal magnetic field due to repulsion from the external field. This effect arises from the behavior of electrons orbiting atomic nuclei, creating induced currents that produce a magnetic moment opposite to the applied field, resulting in repulsion.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Common diamagnetic materials include bismuth, copper, lead, and water. Superconductors, when cooled to extremely low temperatures, exhibit perfect diamagnetism, expelling all magnetic field lines from their interior, known as the Meissner effect.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Paramagnetic substances weakly magnetize in an external field, moving toward stronger fields and slightly attracting magnets. Each atom, ion, or molecule possesses a permanent magnetic dipole moment, but random thermal motion prevents net magnetization. In a strong external field $B_0$ and low temperatures, individual dipole moments align with $B_0$, enhancing the field within. Paramagnetic materials include aluminum, sodium, calcium, and oxygen. data.name: paragraph
data.body: Ferromagnetic substances get strongly magnetised when placed in an external magnetic field, moving from a weak to a strong magnetic field.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Ferromagnetic materials, like iron and cobalt, exhibit complex behavior in magnetic fields. Their magnetisation depends on their magnetic history, with hysteresis being a notable phenomenon. This means that for a given magnetic field strength, the resulting magnetisation is not unique but depends on the material's previous magnetic state.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Individual atoms in ferromagnetic materials possess a dipole moment and spontaneously align in domains. These domains exhibit net magnetisation, increasing in size when exposed to an external magnetic field.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Permanent magnets retain ferromagnetic properties over time. They can be made by repeatedly hammering an iron rod or stroking a steel rod with a bar magnet. Alternatively, a ferromagnetic rod can be magnetized by placing it in a solenoid and passing a current through it.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Materials for permanent magnets need high retentivity and coercivity. Steel, alnico, cobalt steel, and ticonal are common choices. Electromagnets use ferromagnetic cores with high permeability and low retentivity, like soft iron. When a current passes through a solenoid with a soft iron core, magnetism increases greatly. Electromagnets find use in various applications, from electric bells to cranes.
